review.title: Exact MAP Inference by Avoiding Fractional Vertices
review.abstract: Given a graphical model, one essential problem is MAP inference, that is, finding the most likely configuration of states according to the model. Although this problem is NP-hard, large instances can be solved in practice. A major open question is to explain why this is true. We give a natural condition under which we can provably perform MAP inference in polynomial time. We require that the number of fractional vertices in the LP relaxation exceeding the optimal solution is bounded by a polynomial in the problem size. This resolves an open question by Dimakis, Gohari, and Wainwright. In contrast, for general LP relaxations of integer programs, known techniques can only handle a constant number of fractional vertices whose value exceeds the optimal solution. We experimentally verify this condition and demonstrate how efficient various integer programming methods are at removing fractional solutions.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 170 3.02 689v 1 [stat.MIn view of a graphical model, a major problem is the MAP inference, i.e. finding the most likely configuration of states according to the model. Although this problem is NP-hard, large instances can be solved in practice. An important open question is why this is. We specify a natural condition under which we can demonstrably perform MAP inferences in the polynomial time. We require that the number of breakpoints in the LP relaxation exceeding the optimal solution be limited by a polynomial of the problem size. This solves an open question of Dimakis, Gohari, and Wainwright. In contrast, known techniques for general LP relativization of integer programs can only handle a constant number of breakpoints whose value exceeds the optimal solution. We test this condition experimentally and show how efficient different integral fractional solution solutions are.

sections.heading: 2 Background and Related Work
sections.text: For some classes of graphical models, it is possible to solve the MAP problem precisely. See [32] for balanced and nearly balanced models, [15] for perfect graphs, and [30] for graphs with constant tree width. These conditions are often incorrect in practice, and a variety of general algorithms are able to solve the MAP problem for large inputs. One class is belief propagation and its variants [35, 29, 28]. Another class includes general ILP optimization methods (see e.g. [24]). Techniques that specialize in graphical models include cutting-plane methods based on cycle inequalities [26, 19, 27]. See also [16] for a comparative overview of technical methods. In [34], the authors examine how pseudomarginals and relaxations are closely related to the success of the Bethe approximation of the partition function [34].
